entry.intent: Acknowledge the craving and move the user into a supported state.
coachMessages: I’m glad you reached out the moment the craving hit. Let’s work through it together.
You’re safe here. This feeling is your body rebalancing, not a sign you’re failing.
userPrompts: Invite the user to describe what the craving feels like right now.
Offer to guide them through a short relief sequence.
improvNotes: Affirm that needing help is expected and a step toward freedom.

relief.intent: Guide the user through breathing, observation, physical release, and reframing to reduce craving intensity.
coachMessages: Let’s take one slow breath together. Inhale gently through your nose… and exhale through your mouth. Feel your body begin to settle.
Now notice the craving like a small wave of energy. You don’t have to stop it — just watch it rise, crest, and fall.
Check in with your body for a moment. Are your shoulders lifted? Let them drop, just a little. Unclench your jaw. Let your hands rest loosely.
That calm you feel now — that’s real release. It’s your body rebalancing itself, not nicotine fixing anything.
You’re not missing out on anything right now. What you feel isn’t a need for nicotine — it’s your body coming back into balance.
userPrompts: Ask the user to rate their craving from 1–10 before and after the relief exercise.
Invite them to describe any sensations that changed — warmth, lightness, calm, or focus.
Encourage them to notice how quickly the craving softened once they stopped resisting.
improvNotes: Deliver one line at a time with short pauses between each instruction.
Keep tone gentle and voice pacing slow; the experience should feel embodied, not cognitive.
Celebrate even small drops in craving intensity as real wins.
Avoid any mention of willpower, suppression, or ‘fighting’ the craving.

extendedCoachMessages.text: Let’s take one slow breath together.
Inhale gently through your nose… two… three… four.
Now exhale through your mouth… three… four.
Good. Notice the craving like a small wave of energy.
You don’t have to stop it — just watch it rise… crest… and fall.
Are your shoulders lifted? Let them drop, just a little.
Unclench your jaw, soften your face.
Let your hands rest loosely on your lap.
That calm you feel now is real release — calm you created yourself.
You’re not missing out on anything right now.
What you felt was just your body coming back into balance.
On a scale of one to ten, how strong is the craving now?

reflection.intent: Spark curiosity about why cravings appear and how nicotine maintains them.
coachMessages: That feeling has faded — incredible work. Want to know why it showed up in the first place?
Most people think nicotine calms them, yet it’s nicotine that creates the tension it then masks.
userPrompts: Offer a choice: dive deeper now or save the insight for later.
When the user opts in, share one short myth-busting insight.
improvNotes: Honor a user’s choice to skip and move toward the teaser stage gracefully.
Keep explanations short and grounded in everyday language.

teaser.intent: Paint a vision of life without cravings and connect to the Freedom Journey offer.
coachMessages: Imagine moving through your day without cravings tugging at you — that’s what freedom feels like.
Nicotine only feels powerful because of a few sneaky illusions. Once you see through them, the cravings collapse.
userPrompts: Invite the user to preview Lesson 1 of the Freedom Journey.
Offer to send a reminder for the next craving if they’re not ready.
improvNotes: Keep momentum gentle and encouraging, never pushy.
Link the teaser back to the win they just experienced.

conversion.intent: Guide the user toward checkout or waitlist while reinforcing value.
coachMessages: You’ve proven you can ride out cravings. The Freedom Journey shows you how to dissolve them entirely.
Lesson 1 is a free preview — it reveals why nicotine’s ‘stress relief’ is an illusion.
userPrompts: Present the CTA: continue to secure checkout or join the waitlist.
Reassure them they can return to the craving companion anytime.
improvNotes: Keep the offer clear: 6 guided conversations based on the Easy Way method.
Celebrate their progress and close with an open invitation to come back.
